title: 110_s2215
content: The "Supporting America's Protective Security Advisor Act of 2007" establishes the Protective Security Advisor Program Office under the Homeland Security Act of 2002. The Protective Security Advisor Program Office, established under the Homeland Security Act of 2002, is responsible for encouraging collaboration in the risk management framework of the National Infrastructure Protection Plan and coordinating critical infrastructure activities with governments and private sector entities. The Protective Security Advisor Program Office, established under the Homeland Security Act of 2002, is responsible for enhancing critical infrastructure and key resources preparedness through risk assessment analyses, promoting information sharing and security awareness, assisting in developing security plans, ensuring coordination between various levels of government and stakeholders, and advising on nationally critical infrastructure issues. The Secretary shall develop a plan for the assignment and distribution of protective security advisors to enhance critical infrastructure preparedness and coordinate with international security partners. The plan developed shall ensure protective security advisors are located nationwide, with a focus on high-risk areas and additional advisors in densely populated regions with critical infrastructure. Minimum requirements include assigning advisors based on risk levels. The plan developed under paragraph (1) ensures that at least 1 protective security advisor is located in each State, with at least 10 supervisory advisors located throughout the United States for regional coordination. Each supervisory advisor will have appropriate support staff, and the Office headquarters will include at least 2 protective security advisors for management. The plan ensures the presence of protective security advisors in each State and supervisory advisors for regional coordination. Additionally, it mandates the management of special events, training programs, exercise programs, training and standards program, and day-to-day contingency operations by protective security advisors. The Secretary must submit a report to Congress within 90 days outlining the plan developed for responding to natural disasters or terrorist events. Biennial reporting on the Office's activities is required, and $40,000,000 is authorized for fiscal years 2009 and beyond.
